instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
Another board I am a bit baffled with. <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (2013). Stuck at the beginning with this one as PP3v42 is at 2.8v. 

No magsafe light but then it DOES get a magsafe light, but voltage stays at 2.8v

That suggests something is draining it.  Scratching my head with this one. Ther was some liquid damage in the past around <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> by the discolouration of the cap and resistors, so I replaced <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and all components there as a matter of course. Same.

I have also reballed the SMC as there was some signs of alcohol cleaning that had been done around there, so just to be sure. Same.

I would be happy for any pointers to get me started on this one. I know it is old and not worth much, but it would be nice to get tuis one working all the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
Did you read Vout formula from page 49?
Play with <RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR>/96 until correct the voltage.
Check first if resistors have nominal values.
Also test removing <CAPACITOR>C7095</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
Thanks for your input again.

Yes, that is interesting regarding Vout. I am assuming that because there is a limit of 300ma and the resistnace has not changed, then the chip must be implimenting ohms law and choking the voltage.

So, removed <CAPACITOR>C7095</CAPACITOR> - voltage dropped to 1.6v.

Repolaced <CAPACITOR>C7095</CAPACITOR> with new, back to 2.8v

Removed and checked <RESISTOR>R7095</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7096</RESISTOR>, both tested exactly correct at 349k and 198k (my multimeter is not that accurate, but those numbers are good IMHO). Put those back.

So concluded it must be <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> ad replaced <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> and now have 3.42 back. At the moment board is drawing 109ma, so time for a list of testing, but I did briefly check and have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> as well as the 5v and 3.3v rails. Also magsafe light now, so making progress........

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
PP1v2 is 1.05v???

PP1v8 is 0v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
"PP1v2 is 1.05v???"
Did you check at pin 2 of L7430?

Post all <CHIP>U7820</CHIP> voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
OK, somewhere along here I have got teh board mixed up. This is actually another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - my apologies.

Yes, pin 1 is 104.7v, pin 2 is 105.3v

<CHIP>U7820</CHIP>
Pin 1:     3.345v
Pin 2:     3.344v
Pin 3:     60.8mV
Pin 4:    3.346v
Pin 5:    0v
Pin 6:    0.808v
Pin7:    0v
Pin 8:    1.803v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
Now suddenly getting 1.8v of course. Just to annoy me. LOL.

CPU warm, no more. 200ma draw

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
"Yes, pin 1 is 104.7v, pin 2 is 105.3v"
Please do NOT mix the things more.
I bet such board with 100V will explode!
For the future, do NOT write again a diode mode value with end "V"; and put the period sign in its place.

Do you get CPU core voltage now?
What about <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?
The board makes the classic 3 start attempts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
Sorry, meant to put 1.047v  and 1.053v Apologies. 

Voltages are NOT diode mode. They are live voltages. That is why I put v.

Board will not do 3 starts as it is an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> as per my last post.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
I forgot you've said is 00165 indeed.

What about the other things I mentioned in previous post?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
<CHIP>U2701</CHIP> pins:
3.3
0
0
0
3.3

No CPU Vcore

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
What is <CHIP>U2701</CHIP>?
I suppose you are missing <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> goes high?
Post voltage for pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
Very sorry - I was tired when I typed, my apologies. <CHIP>U2071</CHIP> - you asked about <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> so that is where I checked it amd also included the other readings from that chip.

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is missing

Current now holding around 150ma and as you will guess from that number, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is missing.

Pins 3 & 7 on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> are both 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
OK. [B]All fixed.[/B]

The voltage at L7430 WAS 1.05v but obviously should have been 1.2v. So I checked above <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> at <RESISTOR>R7425</RESISTOR> and it was showing as OL instread of 0 ohm. Replaced that and the cap <CAPACITOR>C7425</CAPACITOR> (as I was there anyway) and it now works perfectly.

Thanks again for your amazing and encouraging input. I got there in the end anyway but as per my tag line, I always try to help if I can hence saying what the problem was. 

This board had multiple issues, but has moved from the scrap pile into a working machine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
Thanks for feedback, will help someone else on the forum.

For the future, when you only get partially voltages from S3 and/or S0 states, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is a MUST check signal.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
I spoke too soon. :(

Was working perfectly. Put through ultrasonic and now (fuly dried off)  it is playing games again. Would not work, the  worked perectly for an hour or so. Turned off and......

Now plug magsafe, get green light, no fan spin. Very quick pulse of 5v and shuts down sitting at 20ma. I think 20ma is missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL>... so will have another look tomorrow.

Nice when it works, but if any of my repairs fail I am hgappy to say so with updates as to what it actually is when I find out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
"Put through ultrasonic"
Really need to do that with working board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
Yes. I put a repaired board through an ultrasonic. In fact, I cannot think of any other time to put one in unless of course you are suggesting that you should ultrasonic the board BEFORE you start smothering it in flux?

It isn't Apirl 1st today is it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
Do not make use of ultrasonic bath in excess.
I forgot last time when I used mine.
Don't use it to clean small areas; better toothbrush and IPA then.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message: Oh, this board had many repairs. If I am only replacing say an <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>, I might not ultrasonic, but more than one chip or anytime I do an SMC, ultrasonic everytime.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
Ooops, if replace SMC is supposed to clean the board in that area (toothbrush), once SMC is removed.
As for resolder it only need very little amount of flux (almost not), why to ultrasonic entire board after???
I hope you don't use "chinese honey" in repair process; buy quality flux, from serious store.

Do not expect miracles from ultrasonic cleaner, avoid to stress the board without real reason.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
Of course you have to clean the SMC area once chip is removed, desoldered pads with wick. I hope you didn't think I would do otherwise.

But when you have done several repairs on the same board, you will end up with a sticky board at best if you clean with IPA and a toothbrush with flux trapped under and between some chips etc. Flux is corrosive. Needs to be removed.

And unless I am very much mistaken, doesn't the owner of this very forum Mr Rossmann have hundreds of videos on youtube in which he stresses to ultasonic the boards when finished?

I disagree with stressing the board. I say stress that board as much as you can. If it survives that it will continue working, if it fails because of a 4 minute bubble bath it is going to fail in use anyway.

I respect you clear knowledge of these boards, but I am sorry to disagree over ultrasonic use.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message:
Not had much chance to look at this today, busy sorting other boards. BUT I will say that it would not start. Then starts and runs fine fine. Then will not start.

So, intermittent - the worst of all faults.  All I can tell so far is that when it won't start 5v inductor shows zero. But then an hour later it starts and of course it shows 5v as normal.

Like taking your car to the bgarage then it will not make that noise.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp3v42 is 2.8v
threads.message: Solved. Cracked trace between <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R5127</RESISTOR>. Wire and fixed. Running perfect all afternoon.
